en: Barocci Drawings: Black chalk

Black chalk is carbonaceous shale made mainly of graphite minerals or other amorphous carbons. It is a dry drawing medium. Cennini describes its qualities and mentions that it was found in Piedmont. It was extensively used in Italy from the second half of the 15th century because it was suitable both for making thick lines for large-scale drawings and thin lines on smaller sheets.

description: Black chalk is carbonaceous shale made mainly of graphite minerals or other amorphous carbons. It is a dry drawing medium. Cennini describes its qualities and mentions that it was found in Piedmont. It was extensively used in Italy from the second half of the 15th century because it was suitable both for making thick lines for large-scale drawings and thin lines on smaller sheets.

en: R18: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin and the two children, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk on yellow paper, (27.8 x 23 cm), (inv. KdZ 20525 (3777), Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett) The rapidly sketched upper part of this drawing reveals that Barocci had already established the relationship between the figures. His main concern in this study is to outline the position of the Virgin’s legs and feet and, consequently, the fall of her drapery. This is clearly evident in the lower part of the sheet in his use of black and white chalks to emphasize areas of light and shadow. The basket and the little table visible on the lower right of the painting had probably not been addressed at this stage. © Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett / Jörg P. Anders (3324x2799px)

R19: Federico Barocci, Nude study for the Virgin, before 1575–6, red and white chalk with some black chalk on yellow paper, (19.2 x 15.9 cm), (inv. KdZ 20140 (4156), Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett) Barocci frequently made life studies to prepare the complex poses in his pictures, insisting on his models’ comfort so that his painted figures would appear natural. Here, a nude workshop assistant poses for the Virgin in ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’. Revisions to the feet and right hand (pointing at a black chalk squiggle standing for the cat) reveal that Barocci was still refining these elements. The yellow paper provides a warm mid-tone for the hatched shadows and white chalk highlights. © Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett / Jörg P. Anders (3476x2869px)

R20: Federico Barocci, Study for Saint John's Right Arm and Hand with the Goldfinch, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk on blue paper, (19.3 x 17.8 cm), (inv. KdZ 20518 (4244), Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett) Barocci is a celebrated animal painter. After having studied the anatomy of Saint John the Baptist’s right arm in this rather damaged sheet, he focuses on the saint’s hand holding the animated goldfinch. He depicts the bird in detail and experiments with the pose of its head and its legs. The bird’s form and placement are a primary concern for him, but he is also exploring how to create the dynamism revealed in the saint’s arm holding the restless goldfinch, which is shown ready to retreat after the cat’s imminent pounce. © Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett / Volker-H. Schneider (3598x3324px)

R21: Federico Barocci, Study of drapery for the Virgin, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk on blue paper, (27.4 x 39.7 cm), (inv. KdZ 20529 (4324), Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett) It is plausible that Barocci sketched the drapery study on the left of this sheet from a life model. It is also tempting to assume that a clothed male model was used due to the omission of the breast in the sketch. However, this conclusion cannot be firmly established as the figure of the Virgin is partly covered by the position of Christ in the finished painting. The pose of the Virgin’s left arm with the long folding drapery of the sleeve differs from the one in ‘The Madonna of the Cat ('La Madonna del Gatto')’. Barocci might have carried out this drawing quite early on in the preparatory stages and he may also have used some of these studies in other compositions. © Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett / Volker-H. Schneider (3584x5024px)

R22: Federico Barocci, Study of drapery for the Virgin, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk on blue paper, (26 x 22.6 cm), (inv. KdZ 20524 (4399), Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett) Barocci worked on this drawing from different angles and possibly returned to it on two separate occasions. He began by studying the fall of the drapery over the outstretched legs of the Virgin using red and white chalk, focusing in particular on what will become the blue and yellow part of her skirt in the finished painting. He then turned the sheet upside-down and executed three black chalk sketches to investigate how the Virgin’s green mantle stretches over the nipple of her exposed breast. © Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett / Jörg P. Anders (3124x2760px)

R23: Federico Barocci, Nude study for 'The Madonna of the Cat' ('La Madonna del Gatto'), before 1575–6, red and black chalk with white heightening on blue paper, (24.7 x 19.5 cm), (inv. KdZ 20526 (4451) verso, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett) At this stage Barocci had already chosen to position the Virgin with her legs to the left and her head facing right. However, these studies sketched from a male model reveal the moment when he decided to position the Virgin with her legs crossed. In these three studies in red chalk Barocci begins to explore the relationship between Mary, Saint John the Baptist (on the left) and Saint Joseph (on the lower right), although at this stage he is still far from his final composition. © Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett / Volker-H. Schneider (4796x3852px)

R24: Federico Barocci, Sketch for 'The Madonna of the Cat' ('La Madonna del Gatto'), before 1575–6, pen and ink, wash and red and black chalk on white paper, (21.7 x 10.7 cm), (inv. 1412 E recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe degli Uffizi, Florence) In this ‘primo pensiero’ (first thought) Barocci is pursuing the idea, inspired by the works of Raphael, of placing the two embracing cousins, Saint John the Baptist and Christ, on the Virgin’s lap. However, it is interesting to note that he has not yet thought of introducing the central theme of the painting: the cat chasing the goldfinch, which will distinguish this composition from the traditional Holy Family iconography. As a result, scholars think that this sketch is one of the first surviving preparatory drawings for ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’. © Photo Scala, Florence - courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (3660x1819px)

R26: Federico Barocci, Virgin and Child with Saint John, before 1575–6, black chalk and pen and ink with white heightening on white paper, (15.5 x 11 cm), (inv. 11542 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe, Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence) This sheet, which has been cut down from its original size, shows a composition closely related to another drawing from the Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe degli Uffizi, Florence (R24). In both studies the two children are about to kiss each other. However, in this drawing, which is in worse condition, Barocci uses the technique of white heightening to depict the light effects used in the mother and child group. It is clear that Barocci had already decided at this stage that the light source for his painting should be placed to the left of the composition. © By courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (3687x2648px)

R27: Federico Barocci, Study for Saint John, before 1575–6, black and red chalk on white paper, (16.7 x 17 cm), (inv. 11519 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe, Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence) This study is mainly dedicated to the figure of Saint John the Baptist. The black chalk drawing in the centre depicts the saint’s bust with his left arm embracing the foot of Jesus. Barocci also studied the child’s right armpit on the top left of the sheet. At this stage he must have been happy with the position and expression of the saint and did not change them further in the final painting. The use of red chalk on Saint John’s face in this sketch is a very good example of Barocci’s fascination with light effects. © By courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (3834x3832px)

R29: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin and Child with Saint John, before 1575–6, black chalk and pen and ink on white paper, (10.2 x 17.1 cm), (inv. 11453 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe, Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence) Unfortunately, the condition of this delicate pen and ink drawing makes it hard to interpret. At the back, the three figures are shown aligned with the Virgin and the Christ Child leaning towards Saint John the Baptist who can be seen at the front of the composition. Saint John is sketched using such faint lines that is hard to determine what he is doing. © By courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (2535x1749px)

R31.1: Federico Barocci, Study for 'The Madonna of the Cat' ('La Madonna del Gatto'), before 1575–6, black, white and red chalk on blue paper, (21.6 x 17 cm), (inv. 11555 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe degli Uffizi, Florence) Although this drawing is in poor condition, it offers the possibility of following the development of the composition. The group of the two children and the Virgin Mary is fully established at this point, but the background is very different from the one found in the final painting. On the left, Barocci draws what appears to be the Virgin’s bed and on the right he shows a window with an open shutter, and the figure of Saint Joseph leaning on the window sill. This drawing along with other compositional studies, reveals how complex it was for Barocci to introduce the figure of Saint Joseph into the composition. © Photo Scala, Florence - courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (3284x2595px)

R31.2: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin and Saint Joseph, before 1575–6, black chalk with white heightening on blue paper, (21.6 x 17 cm), (inv. 11555 F verso, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe degli Uffizi, Florence) The relationship between this drawing and ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’ has been questioned. The poses of the models in this sheet seem more similar to the figures painted in Barocci’s ‘Rest on the Return from Egypt’ (1570–3), which was painted for the same patron and a version of which can be found today in the Vatican Museum, Rome. However, the figure dressed in contemporary clothes, softly drawn in red chalk on the lower right, is connected to the early studies for Saint Joseph in the National Gallery painting. © By courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (4686x3636px)

R33: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin's right hand, before 1575–6, black and red chalk on white paper, (12 x 28.5 cm), (inv. 11583 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe, Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence) In this main study for the Virgin’s right hand, Barocci is still thinking of showing the three external fingers flexed inside the palm and providing a frontal view of her thumb. He will remain uncertain as to how to depict the hand until he reproduces it on canvas. Even at this stage, the painting’s underdrawing reveals that he explored several possibilities before choosing to depict a somewhat open hand. Visible on the right is a sketch for the upper part of the hand, while on the left the artist has turned the sheet round to study the fall of the drapery over the Virgin’s exposed breast once again. © By courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (2651x6351px)

R34: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin's Right Hand and for the Right Arm of Saint John, before 1575–6, black and red chalk on white paper, (12.7 x 17.1 cm), (inv. 11593 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe degli Uffizi, Florence) Barocci spent a long time considering the feature of the Virgin’s pointing hand. Here he has masterly studied it in red chalk. In addition, he also uses this sheet to study Saint John the Baptist’s arm with the squiggle representing the goldfinch in his hand. Below right, Barocci with very thin lines of red chalk sketched the Virgin’s mantle above her naked breast. This section concerned him as he had to transform his study of a male model into a female figure in the painting. As a result, it has been suggested that the green mantle was developed in order to help him obtain the correct proportions. © Photo Scala, Florence - courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (2643x3528px)

R35: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin's Right Arm and Hand, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk, charcoal and white heightening on blue paper, (41 x 26.7 cm), (inv. 11635 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe, Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence) This drawing may possibly be the last of the series dedicated to the key feature of the Virgin’s right hand. Barocci here explored both her hand and her arm. In the upper part of the drawing he first looked at a naked arm (on the left and in the centre) and then he drew it again clothed (on the right). In the bottom part of the sheet he seems to have defined the final position of the Virgin’s right thumb suppressing the view of her nail, as he does in the painting. The drapery study on the bottom right is probably for the white cloth in the basket to the right of the composition. © By courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (2796x4330px)

R36: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin's head, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk and pink, ochre and brown pastel with stump on blue paper, reinforced with blue paper, and laid down on board, (35.4 x 24.4 cm), (inv. 1960:99-TR870/1, Smith College of Art Northampton, Massachusetts) Of the existing head studies for the Virgin in ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’, this one is the most individualized. It is probable that Barocci remodelled it from one of his previous head studies at a very late stage in the compositional process. The face is created using a light outline in black chalk, then the design is reinforced with various coloured chalks. Finally, Barocci uses black and red chalk once again for the background and the curls of hair. Although the artist smudged the pastels to some extent to harmonize the tonal relations, the extraordinary strength and density of the lines is clearly visible throughout the various stages of his drawing process. © Smith College of Art Northampton, Massachusetts (4892x3688px)

R37: Federico Barocci, Two studies for the Child's head, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk with peach pastel on blue paper laid down on a 18th-century mat, (26.8 x 23 cm), (inv. 2869 recto, Musée du Louvre, Paris) These studies for the Christ Child’s head were probably made from life. In the main study the model looks down, smiling pacifically, as Christ does in the painting. In the more rapid subsidiary sketch he is chuckling with his mouth and eyes open, an expression ultimately adopted for Saint John the Baptist. The cool blue colour of the paper offered Barocci a broad range of tonal contrasts: the pearly sheen of the infant’s skull offsets the warmth of his chubby cheeks and chin. © RMN-Grand Palais (musée du Louvre) / Thierry Le Mage (5560x4920px)

R41: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin's head, about 1575, black, red and white chalk with pink and brown pastel on faded blue paper, (22.2 x 18.5 cm), (inv. 5230, Royal Collection Trust) This ethereal study for the Virgin’s head, similar in scale to that in ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’ painting, appears at once sublimely idealised yet remarkably lifelike. It may in fact be based on a young workshop assistant. Barocci’s subtly blended flesh tones and beautiful coral-coloured accents in the facial features and ear survive despite the sheet’s damaged condition. Royal Collection Trust / © Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II 2013 (3255x2706px)

R43.1: Federico Barocci, Compositional study for Cornelis Cort's Print of 'The Madonna of the Cat' ('La Madonna del Gatto'), before 1577, black and red chalk, with touches of white bodycolour, indented with squared lines on white paper, (30 x 23.8 cm), (inv. 1994-5-14-55 recto, The British Museum, London) Barocci made this copy drawn after ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’ to send to the Dutch printmaker Cornelis Cort in Rome as a scale model for an engraving. Barocci used three colours of chalk to convey the depth and warmth of the painting, which remained in the Marches. The incised outlines and squaring reveal Cort’s methods for transferring the design to the copper plate from which his engraving (1577), was printed in reverse. Even if this is not a proper cartoncino (small cartoon) and it was made after the completion of the painting, it shows the high level of finish which Barocci was seeking in his completed compositional studies. © The British Museum, London (3368x2679px)

R44.2: Federico Barocci, Study for Joseph, Left Arm on the Table, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk on blue paper, (28 x 21.8 cm), (inv. Z 3071 verso, Anhaltische Gemäldegalerie Dessau) More finished than its recto (R44.1), this drawing shows a drapery study for Saint Joseph’s arms. Using black chalk he revises the left sleeve of the saint and explores light and shade effects by means of white heightening. He then draws Saint Joseph’s right sleeve which falls into shadow using red chalk. In this sketch Barocci is primarily interested in the textile itself and not in the hands or the balance of the figure, which appears much more dynamic in the final painting. © Anhaltische Gemäldegalerie Dessau (4666x3499px)

R45: Federico Barocci, Study for the child, 1545–1577, black and white chalk on brown paper, (17 x 16.2 cm), (RP-T-1955-64, Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam) In the past, this drawing has been taken to be a preparatory study for the figure of Christ in ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’. However, not only  does it relate to the National Gallery painting, but it can also be associated with the recently discovered ‘The Virgin Reading, with the Christ Child on her Lap’ in a private collection, as well as other late works by Barocci. In these later works the baby is reversed, with his eyes staring at the viewer. Signs of incisions are evident along almost all the lines defining the child, revealing one of the artist’s distinctive techniques for tracing a motif from one sheet to another. © Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam (2500x2413px)

R46: Federico Barocci, Study probably for Saint Joseph, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk on blue paper, (29.9 x 11.4 cm), (inv. KdZ 20526 (4413) verso, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett) In an early sheet of studies for ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’ in Berlin (R23), and in all likelihood in an initial composition study in Florence (R31.2), Joseph is shown in the foreground leaning on his elbow. In this drawing the artist sketches three studies from a life model displaying variations on the same pose. Ultimately he selected a much more dynamic pose for Joseph in ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’, which implies that these studies from life might have been made at a very early stage of the preparation for the painting. © Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett / Volker-H. Schneider (5253x2427px)

R47: Federico Barocci, Study for a cat, possibly before 1575–6, black and white chalk on blue paper, (14.3 x 13.4 cm), (inv.KdZ 20153 (4345), Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett) Not only was Barocci a great draughtsman, but he was also a great lover of cats. The same tortoiseshell cat frequently recurs in his drawings and paintings, and the model probably belonged to him. Although in reverse, the cat’s hind leg and paw in this drawing is similar to the arrangement of the hind leg of the cat in the National Gallery picture. However the drawing seems to belong to a longer haired feline and it has also been suggested that it may be a study for a lion’s hindquarters. © Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett / Volker-H. Schneider (3797x3635px)

R48: Federico Barocci, Study for the head of a woman looking down, black and red chalk with pink pastel on white paper, (13.5 x 12.8 cm), (inv. 11475 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe, Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence) Despite the fact that the technique of this head study for the Virgin does not differ from the other three sketches which have been accepted here as preparatory studies for ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’, R30, R36 and R41,  the angle of the head in this drawing is slightly different from that in Barocci’s final painting. Since this angle was established at a very early stage in the preparatory process, it may be that this is an early drawing for another composition. © By courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (3033x2832px)

R49: Federico Barocci, Study for a Child, black chalk on white paper, (12.4 x 7.5 cm), (inv. 11532 F, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe, Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence) This study for a child’s torso might be related to the figure of Saint John the Baptist in ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’. Although slightly different one could speculate that Saint John is indeed on the verge of changing his position as soon as the cat pounces on the goldfinch. This may indicate why Barocci might have been keen to explore the contorted features of a child’s twisted body in this and other preparatory drawings. © By courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (3098x2032px)

R51: Federico Barocci, Study for the head of a woman looking down, possibly before 1575–6, black and red chalk with mixed pastels and lead white on brown paper, (23.7 x 21.2 cm), (inv. 2866 recto, Musée du Louvre, Paris) As is the case with R48 the angle of the Virgin’s head in this drawing is slightly different from that observed in the final painting. The fact that this angle was established at a very early stage in the preparatory process suggests that this is not a study for this painting. Barocci sketched a veil over the woman’s head with few lines of white chalk still visible on the right side of her face. The sheet has been altered and its condition greatly compromises the subtle effect of the mixed pastels. © RMN-Grand Palais (musée du Louvre) / Thierry Le Mage (4840x3780px)

R52: Federico Barocci, Study for Saint Joseph, before 1575–6, red and black chalk on white paper, (39.5 x 24.3 cm), (inv. 647 recto, Biblioteca Oliveriana, Pesaro) Barocci’s early idea for the figure of Saint Joseph leaning his elbow on the table, might have been taken from this life drawing now in Pesaro, which is closely related o the study of the same figure in Berlin (R46). It is possible that the drawing may have been made near the time Barocci painted ‘Il Perdono’ (1571–6), in the church of San Francesco in Urbino, as a study for this composition appears on the same sheet. It is therefore hard to establish conclusively whether this is a preparatory drawing for ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’ or not. © Biblioteca Oliveriana, Pesaro (5051x3431px)

R53: Federico Barocci, Study for the head of a woman looking down, about 1590–1610, black, red and white chalk and brown pastel on blue paper, (25.6 x 19.8 cm), (inv. 5229, Royal Collection Trust) The relationship between this drawing and ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’ is still debated. In this study, Barocci is not as interested in the depiction of the skin or of the woman’s facial features as he is in other head studies. His concern here lies instead in defining the woman’s hair. He alternates thin lines of black chalk with smudged brown pastel to render the depiction of the hair as natural as possible. His use of colours also tells us that the source of light was placed to the left of the composition. Royal Collection Trust / © Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II 2013 (4078x3319px)

R56: Federico Barocci, Sketch for the Virgin and Child with Saint John, before 1575–6, black chalk, pen and ink with wash on white paper, (30.3 x 23.4 cm), (inv. 11477 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe degli Uffizi, Florence) This sheet records Barocci’s rapid initial trials for the group of the Virgin and two children in ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’). He began experimenting in black chalk, but then inverted the sheet to continue a new series of drawings in pen and wash. His main concerns were the distribution of light and shadow, and the young John the Baptist’s dynamic diagonal pose. Barocci’s sensitive use of wash highlights key passages such as the Virgin’s bare breast and the children’s joyful expressions. © Photo Scala, Florence - courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (3207x2539px)

NG29: Federico Barocci, The Madonna of the Cat ('La Madonna del Gatto'), probably about 1575, Oil on canvas, (112.7 x 92.7 cm) The young John the Baptist holds a goldfinch, a bird frequently kept as a pet but also a traditional symbol of Christ's Passion; the Baptist is teasing the cat shown in the left foreground by holding the bird above his head. The Virgin is suckling the Child and Saint Joseph looks on from the right.
NG 29 may be the picture painted, according to Bellori (1672), for Count Antonio Brancaleoni, who lived near Perugia. The design was engraved in reverse in 1577 by Cornelius Cort and the painting probably dates from about 1575. Numerous drawings made in preparation for NG 29 are known; a highly finished drawing made by Barocci in preparation for the engraving and formerly in the National Gallery is now in the British Museum.
The window and the bench in the background seem to be based on windows in the Palazzo Ducale, Urbino. There are several copies and workshop versions of the picture.
Cesarei collection, Perugia, by 1784; acquired in Italy by Buchanan, about 1805; collection of Revd Holwell Carr, 1807; by whom bequeathed, 1831.
Gould 1975, pp. 11-12
Emiliani 1985, I, pp. 93-103 Bequeathed by Revd Holwell Carr, 1831 (6000x4929px)
